awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Molecular-level Understanding of Small Molecule Transport in Glassy Polymers Exhibiting Configurational Free Volume
awd_abstract_narration:
Many new membrane materials have been developed in recent years; however, very few of them have made it to industrial applications, mainly due to lack of durability and robustness under realistic operating conditions. This research project aims to develop a molecular-level understanding of transport mechanisms in membrane materials and to inform the development of the next generation of membrane materials that can compete with traditional energy-intensive gas separations technologies. The types of membrane materials that will be investigated have a molecular structure that creates permanent, non-collapsible voids (free volume) in the material. The free volume is available for selective gas sorption, and the molecular structure around the voids helps the material to maintain its free volume and separation performance, unlike current separation membranes. The scientific knowledge generated by this research should enable significant advances in separation membranes that will meet the needs for a broad range of industrial applications. The research project serves as a training ground for undergraduate and graduate students to perform cutting edge research and will engage students from groups underrepresented in STEM fields. The researchers will also engage in well-structured education and outreach activities, including developing new courses, formulating educational and research components for high school students, giving presentations at a public "research night" event, and creating an educational video streaming for general public. 

The goal of this research project is to elucidate how conformation- and configuration-based free volume contribute, individually and synergistically, to the membrane transport properties. The research hypothesis is that configurational free volume is much more stable than conformational free volume, and thus it provides unprecedented resistance to physical aging and plasticization even under harsh conditions, i.e., at high temperature and in chemically challenging environments. Iptycene-based polymers with specifically, yet systematically, varied free volume architecture will be synthesized, and the effect of configurational free volume on molecular transport will be studied. Fundamental transport properties (i.e., sorption, diffusion and permeation) will be investigated experimentally and theoretically under both ambient and harsh conditions. Finally, atomistic simulations will be performed to elucidate the underlying transport mechanism in polymers with configuration-based free volume and the effect of nano-confinement. The outcome of this project will be improved membranes for industrial gas separations, especially under harsh conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Microporous polymers emerged, in the last decade, as promising gas separation membrane materials offering high permeability. However, they suffer from low selectivity, and more significantly, poor resistance to physical aging and plasticization. This collaborative project, which included a chemical engineer, a polymers chemist and a computation chemist, interrogated the fundamentally new concept of ?configuration-based free volume? as a solution to these grand challenges faced by existing microporous polymers, whose free volume is primarily based on transient conformational features (e.g., inefficient packing due to restricted rotation). We demonstrated that polymers containing iptycene moieties exhibit exceptional size sieving ability, and are aging and plasticization resistant, due to the existence of unique ?internal free volume? delineated by iptycene molecular configuration. We defined this internal free volume as configurational free volume, which, as opposed to the transient nature of conformational free volume in conventional glassy polymers, is related to the permanent molecular configuration. This project developed a previously unavailable fundamental understanding of the connection between free volume microporosity and properties for iptycene-based polymers, thus generating new transformative concepts across fields, such as polymer chemistry, polymer physics and separation science. This project elucidates, for the first time ever, how conformation- and configuration-based free volume contribute, individually and synergistically, to the membrane properties. To do so, a class of thermally rearranged polybenzoxazoles exhibiting systematically varied amount of triptycene units (i.e., configurational free volume) was synthesized, characterized and modelled. We discovered that triptycene units do not affect light gas sorption, while precisely regulating their diffusion, thus offering a unique size-sieving ability, whose molecular mechanism was elucidated quantitatively. In contrast, configurational free volume suppresses, via a purely entropic mechanism, the solubility of bulkier vapor molecules in the polymer, leading sorption- and diffusion-selectivity to work synergistically instead than against each other, ultimately offering an unexpectedly high sorption-selectivity that can even exceed the size sieving ability. This discovery has implications in liquid separations, other than in gas separation solely. We also discovered the superior swelling resistance of configuration-based polymer membranes, which is much higher than in conventional gas separation materials.

The project goals were fully achieved, by changing the way to think about free volume and teaching the general public how to exquisitely design and manipulate polymers free volume to achieve previously unattainable membrane properties.   

 

Broader Impact

The knowledge gained from this project enabled a more rational design of advanced materials for energy-efficient separations and provided new solutions to the grand materials challenges in the membrane separation field. The ideas developed within this project can be readily extended to other systems involving molecular or ion transport, such as batteries, desalination, and liquid separations. Equally important, this multidisciplinary project has been an educational vehicle to involve students at all levels in science and engineering via well-structured education and outreach activities, spanning from attracting underrepresented students into research, to formulating educational and research components for high school students and involving students? families in creative activities. These activities greatly helped enhance the literacy of the general public in Oklahoma, a high need area with a still high poverty rate.

 

Relevant Outcomes

The new knowledge developed within this project translated into four scholarly publications in high impact journals, such as the Journal of Membrane Science (IF 10), plus three additional papers in preparation for publication. All of them have graduate or undergraduate students as first authors. One of these papers was selected as the Editors? Choice in the Journal of Membrane Science, which recognizes papers bringing brand-new and potentially transformative ideas into the field.

About 15 oral presentations were delivered, mostly by students, to spread outcomes from this project at the AIChE, NAMS and ACS meetings. 3 poster presentations related to this project were delivered in the same meetings, one of which ranked first at the NAMS graduate students poster competition (cf. Fig. 1)

Ideas and knowledge developed within this project gave rise to new projects, which are offering unique opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students in Oklahoma and Indiana.

The new transformative concept of configurational free volume was introduced, for the first time, to teach our peer and the broader public not only how to make better membranes exhibiting higher selectivity and stability, but also elucidating the fundamental molecular mechanisms by which these results are achieved. This fact made this project clearly distinct from other projects, which often focus only on ?Edisonian? material synthesis, with little or no molecular understanding of the phenomena underpinning selectivity and stability.

The scholarly value of the three PIs benefitted enormously from this project, as all of them received prestigious international awards for their research and educational activities, often motivated by the outcomes of this project.

 


Last Modified: 09/02/2023
Modified by: Michele Galizia

Image
  • Fig. 1. The PhD student William Box receiving the poster award at NAMS 2023.
    NAMS
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Michele Galizia
    Will Box Award
